For the DARPA TCE3 dataset, since only a minimal number of events in the log data are attacks, selecting all the events can cause some issues for model training. Instead, we select a subset of log data that contains most of the CADETS system‚Äôs attacks. Next, we select events associated with both source and destination objects for the edge classification task in our methodology, yielding 237,721 events, of which 236,160 (99.3%) are benign and 1,561 (0.7%) are attacks. The graph is constructed from selected data using events as edges and objects as nodes. The features of nodes and edges are transformed into sentences, as shown in TABLE
, and then embedded in the output sentence using the pre-trained

S4.T2.caption: Table 2: Sentence patterns for each node and edge types
S4.T2.table:
Type Object/event type Sentence pattern
NODE NET_FLOW A ‚Äúnet_flow‚Äù node has a local address of {{local_address}}, a local port of {{local_port}}, a remote address of {{remote_address}}, and a remote port of {{remote_port}}.
NODE FILE A ‚Äúfile‚Äù node has the subtype of ‚Äú{{sub_type}}‚Äù.
NODE SUBJECT A ‚Äúsubject‚Äù node the has subtype of ‚Äú{{sub_type}}‚Äù.
NODE UNNAMED_PIPE -
EDGE EXECUTE A ‚Äúexecute‚Äù edge executed the ‚Äú{{exec}}‚Äù program, and its command line is ‚Äú{{cmd_line}}‚Äù.
EDGE ACCEPT An ‚Äúrename‚Äù edge accepted the connection from {{address}} with the port of {{port}}, and it executed the ‚Äú{{exec}}‚Äù program.
EDGE MODIFY_PROCESS An ‚Äúmodify_process‚Äù edge executed the ‚Äú{{exec}}‚Äù program.
EDGE CREATE_OBJECT An ‚Äúcreate_object‚Äù edge executed the ‚Äú{{exec}}‚Äù program.
EDGE RENAME An ‚Äúrename‚Äù edge executed the ‚Äú{{exec}}‚Äù program.

references: We simulated the training process of the FL model with 10 clients on an Ubuntu 20.04 virtual machine with 6 core CPUs and 32 GB of RAM in 20 rounds. In our experiments, we use a CNN&GRU model, a variant of DeepFed model, for the NIDS system and E-GraphSAGE for the PIDS system. TABLE

show the architecture for the CNN&GRU model and E-GraphSAGE, respectively. Based on our experiments, we trained all clients with the following configuration to achieve optimal performance on both models:
for the CNN&GRU model, and the same configuration for the E-GraphSAGE model, but with

. In the settings for both NF-ToN-IoT and the DARPA TCE3 dataset, we select 70% of samples for the training set and the remaining 30% for the testing set, while ensuring the ratio of malicious and benign samples to prevent bias in the evaluation process. Finally, the training dataset would be divided equally and distributed to all clients.

S4.T5.caption: Table 5: Detection performance of CNN&GRU and the E-GraphSAGE model in XFedHunter
S4.T5.table:
Accuracy Precision Recall F1-Score
CNN&GRU 0.9969 0.9962 0.9976 0.9969
E-GraphSAGE 0.9995 0.9449 0.9877 0.9658
references: shows the detection metric results for the CNN&GRU model on the NF-ToN-IoT dataset and the E-GraphSAGE model on the DARPA TCE3 dataset. Overall, we can see that the metric results for both models are very high, with the lowest values for the CNN&GRU and E-GraphSAGE models being 0.9962 and 0.9449, respectively. Moreover, although the DARPA TCE3 dataset is dramatically unbalanced in favor of benign events, the E-GraphSAGE model still has a recall metric result of 0.9877, demonstrating the impressive performance of the model in searching for small malicious patterns like APT attacks among large benign events.
